loans.name: Yoeurn

texts.en: Yoeurn, 47, is a loving mother of two unmarried children. Yoeurn and her husband are farmers in a small rice field near their house. They can earn USD 5 a day. Yoeurn would like to improve her living standard by having clean energy for household use. Because of the lack of capital, she is asking for a loan to build a biogas digester, under the NBP (National Biogas Program) project in partnership with HKL. After an initial investment in this system, she hopes that she won’t spend much money on fuel and will lessen the smoke from wood or charcoal. She is very happy and thankful, because with this loan purpose, HKL has provided her a special interest rate compared to its general loan. She awaits your kindness and relies on your generosity.

loans.use: to build a biogas digester

loans.name: Maripat

texts.ru: Марипат добросовестная и порядочная женщина. Она родилась в сельской местности. С детства Марипат помогала родителям по животноводству. После замужества она начала бизнес скотоводством самостоятельно. Она выращивает также картофель, морковь, помидоры, яблоки и груши. Она продает фрукты и овощи на местном рынке. Марипату помогает ее муж введению бизнеса. Она имеет 3 дочерей и одного сына. С честно заработанными деньгами она выдала замуж своих дочерей, и год назад женила сына. Теперь она хочет отремонтировать свой старый дом и с такой целью она обратилась за займом в сумме 1800 сомони для покупки строительных материалов как краски, цемент и т.п. Она ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en:
Maripat is a conscientious and honest woman. She was born in the countryside. 

Since childhood, Maripat helped her parents raise livestock. After marriage, she started a cattle business on her own. She also grows potatoes, carrots, tomatoes, apples and pears. She sells fruit and vegetables at the local market. Maripatu's husband helps her run the business. 

She has three daughters and one son. She paid to marry her daughters with honestly earned money, and one year ago her son also got married. Now she wants to repair her old house and, in order to do that, she applied for a 1,800 TJS loan to buy building materials such as paints and cement. She awaits your kindness.

loans.use: to buy building materials such as cement and paints to repair her old house

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en: Manuel is 66 years old and lives in Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is married with 4 children whom are now adults. Manuel has been engaged in fishing for 20 years now, and earns approximately PHP3,000.00 each month from doing this type of work. He has requested a loan to be used in purchasing additional fishing equipment such as nets, hooks and threads for his existing fishing activity. Manuel has been a member of PMPC for 2 years now. In the future, Manuel hopes to acquire additional fishing boats and fishing equipment in order to increase the family income.

loans.use: to be used for purchasing additional fishing equipment such as nets, hooks and threads

loans.name: Willaflor

texts.en: Willaflor lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur with her family. She earns a good income from farming and has successfully repaid her previous loan which was used for her farm. Her ability in farming has improved and she is now requesting a new loan to purchase fertilizers.  Willaflor will save the returns for sending her children to school and to provide for their daily needs. Willaflor wishes for her farm to grow and be more salable within her community.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy supplies for growing potatoes.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en: Concepcion is 45 years old, married and has four children, of whom two are in school. Concepcion and her family survived Super Typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013, but her business and family home was wiped out. Concepcion is taking out a housing loan amounting PHP 9714.20 to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor in order to build a house for her family. Concepcion has been with NWTF since 2012, and plans to recover through her fish vending business. With your help, Concepcion can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of Super Typhoon Haiyan. In future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Naranbat

texts.en: Mr. Naranbat, 22 years old, lives with his parents and three siblings in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a Mongolian traditional ger (portable felt dwelling) on a plot of land. He has been running an automobile repair workshop since 2012. His father sells wooden crafts to local people and his mother makes dresses at home. His siblings are all underage and stay at home. He is requesting a loan of 2700000 MNT to buy automobile spare parts for his business. This is so that he can run his repair workshop without worrying about inventory shortage.

loans.use: to buy automobile spare parts for his business

loans.name: Johnny

texts.en: Retailing helped Johnny and his family to survive. He retails charcoal and brings in a meager income of Php 6,000 per month. He finds the business of buying and selling charcoal easy and simple because all he needs to do is to weigh and repack the charcoal for his buyers. He plans to expand his retailing business. He has applied for a loan to PMPC for the needed capital. He wants to purchase additional inventory of charcoal for retail. Johnny smiles at the fact to see all his children finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is a married woman with five children, with three children still in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Helen is 38 years old. Helen has a buy and sell gasoline business in the Philippines. Helen has requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional containers of gasoline to sell. Helen has been in this business for 3 years now. In the future, Helen would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional containers of gasoline to sell

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en: Leonida is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business selling purified drinking water in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 12000 through NWTF to buy more containers of purified drinking water to sell for her purified drinking water retail business. Leonida has been in this business for 5 years now. Leonida earns additional income from direct selling Avon products. Leonida has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business in order to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more containers of purified drinking water to sell

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en: Sophal is 42 years old and is a married woman with a child. Her child is a student. She is a worker in a pure drinking water factory. Her husband carries out water selling in the village. They live in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. They can earn approximately $10 per day. Now she would like to apply for a loan of $700 to buy bricks and cement to build a new house because her present house is old. This loan will help her live in better conditions. In the future, she wants to buy a truck for her husband to carry out his water selling in the village, to build the fences around her house and support her child to finish high school.

loans.use: to buy bricks and cement to build a new house

loans.name: Claire

texts.en: Claire works hard to support her family. On November 8, 2013, her business and home were wiped out by Super Typhoon Haiyan. She has restarted her general store business and is now requesting a PHP 7771.40 housing loan through NWTF in order to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor, so she could build a house for her family. With your help, Claire will be able to rebuild her devastated life more quickly. In the future, Claire would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna is 58 years old and lives in Oroquieta. She is married and has been engaged in managing a car radiator repair shop together with her husband as the repairman. She has requested a loan to purchase additional bronze rods, flux, copper and other accessories and materials for their radiator repair shop. Myrna has been a member of PMPC for 8 years. In the future, she hopes to expand their radiator repair shop business.

loans.use: to purchase additional bronze rods, flux, copper and other accessories and materials

loans.name: Garba Lauya

texts.en: Garba Lauya is a 35-year-old farmer from Hayin Malam Yako.  As a Babban Gona member, Garba Lauya is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Garba Lauya can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Garba Lauya is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Garba Lauya is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Jamilu,  and Wasila. Garba Lauya’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Lucita

texts.en:
Lucita works hard to support her family. Lucita is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Lucita requested a 14000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase ingredients for her food production business.

Lucita has been in this business for 20 years now.

In the future, Lucita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Mum

texts.en:
Mum, age 44, is a housewife living in the province of Kampong Speu with her husband and their three children. All three of the children work in the clothes design department of a garment factory. Her husband works as a soil mover. Together, the family can earn approximately $21.59 per day.

She would like to apply for a loan in the amount of $1,000 to buy a motorcycle for her family's use. This loan will help her reduce traveling expenses in her family.

In the future, Mum wants to help her children stop working in the factory and open their own clothing design business.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for her family to use as transportation

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en: Narantsetseg, 54 years old, lives with her two sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband passed away long time ago. She has been running her grocery store for more than ten years. Her elder son graduated from his university and now looking for job. The younger one is currently studying at university and will graduate next year. She is requesting a loan of 3000000 MNT to buy a large amount of foodstuffs. This will help her to generate more income and run her grocery store without worrying about an inventory shortage. The borrower is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to buy a large amount of foodstuffs.

loans.name: Medina

texts.en:
Medina is 27 years old, married and blessed with four children. Due to financial hardship, she engages in a vegetable vending business to supplement her husband's income. 

She aims to acquire more stocks of vegetables to sell but she has insufficient capital. For this reason, she wants to avail additional capital of PHP 10,000 to buy more stocks of cabbages, beans, tomatoes, eggplants, squash, potatoes and more vegetables to sell. Having this financial assistance, Medina believes that she will further improve the business.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of cabbages, beans, tomatoes, eggplants, squash, potatoes and more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en: Lourdes, 34, is married to a driver and they're blessed with two children. She has managed a vegetable vending stand at the public market for almost seventeen years and earns a net income of 800 PHP daily. She usually spends her income from this business on the school allowances of their children. Due to insufficient funds for her business, she's asking for a loan from the generous lenders amounting 25,000 PHP to purchase  more eggplants, tomatoes, string beans, cabbage, sweet potatoes, and squash to sell. She's hoping that her business will continue to grow and become more profitable so that she can earn more income.

loans.use: to purchase eggplants, tomatoes, string beans, cabbage, sweet potatoes, and squash to sell.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 46 years old and married with four children, one of whom is in school. She works very hard to provide for her family.

Josephine's business and family home was destroyed by Super Typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines on November 8, 2013. Josephine has restarted her food vending business and now needs to provide her family with safe shelter.

Josephine has taken a 5985.70 PHP housing loan through NWTF in order to purchase materials to rebuild her family home.

She is using the this loan to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

Josephine is committed to rebuilding her devastated life and in future would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Abdullahi

texts.en: Abdullahi is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Abdullahi joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: . Abdullahi is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Abdullahi will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Abdullahi can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Abdullahi is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Idris

texts.en: Idris is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Idris joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Samaila, Abba and  Zaharau. Idris is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Idris will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Idris can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Idris said “I plan to use the money I make this year to expand my farmland”. Idris is not thinking about just this year; he said, “in 5 years, I want to become the  most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Jona

texts.en:
Jona is a married woman with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Jona is 37 years old and all of her children are in school.

Jona's house was destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. She has restarted her food vending business and is committed to regaining what she lost. 

Jona is taking a PHP 9,485 housing loan through NWTF in order to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family.

Jona has been with NWTF since 2012 in her pursuit to rise out of poverty. With your help, she will be able to start once more in a new home. In the future, Jona would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina is 58 years old, married, and has four children, with one child still in school. Marcelina works very hard to provide for them.

Marcelina runs a general store in the Philippines. Marcelina has been in this business for six years and sells a variety of items such as detergent soap, shampoo, noodles, biscuits, candies, coffee, etc. 

She requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items like detergent soap, shampoo, noodles, biscuits, candies, coffee, etc. to sell.

Marcelina would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items like detergent soap, shampoo, noodles, biscuits, candies, coffee, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Sea

texts.en:
Kimsea, age 29, and her husband are construction workers. Together they can earn approximately $10 per day. They live with their two children in the province of Siem Reap. Both the children attend school.

Kimsea would like to apply for a loan in the amount of $1,000 to buy wood to repair and renovate her house. This loan will help Kimsea and her family live in better conditions. 

In the future, she intends to buy a stall at the market where she can sell clothes. Her goal is to support her children's educations through high school.

loans.use: to buy wood to repair and renovate her family's house

loans.name: Esperidion

texts.en:
Esperidion has a store in Oroquieta and has been in this business for 30 years already. The business helped him meet his family's financial needs, especially the education of his children until they graduated and got jobs. 

He is still continuing the business to pay for utilities. His plan is to maintain his inventory so that he can serve well his customers. He already availed loans previously to purchase additional stocks, and now he is re-applying for a loan for his store to purchase additional grocery items.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for his grocery store.

loans.name: Anas Mohammed

texts.en: Anas Mohammed is a 30-year-old farmer from Hayin Malam Yako.  As a Babban Gona member, Anas Mohammed is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Anas Mohammed can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Anas Mohammed is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; . My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en:
Ahmed is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Ahmed joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Surajo,Ashiru, and Barakiya.
Ahmed is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Ahmed will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Ahmed can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Ahmed is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou works hard to support her family. Marilou is married and has a general store business in the Philippines. Marilou has been in this business for 10 years now.

Marilou requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

Marilou would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Ibrahim joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Tasiu,Razika , and Habibu. Ibrahim is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Ibrahim will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Ibrahim can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Ibrahim is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Sambi Ternak Group

texts.en:
The Sambi Ternak group can pay off the loan on time. During the six months past, the group succeeded in maintaining the pigs. Besides being monitored by the loan officer, they were also visited by the vet regularly, so the pigs could grow well and have a good price.

Ketut, as the head, is responsible for the group and the repayment. As a piglets seller, she succeeded in selling out her piglets. She was very happy for that, and she hopes that she gets more in the next loan to improve her business.

Although most inhabitants here work as fishermen, as the Balinese women, they still maintain a cultural of raising pigs for supporting the family income. 

Ketut will use her loan to purchase three superior piglets and feed. She’s trying a new plan to manage fattening the pigs. She hopes the price for pigs keeps high and she can earn a satisfactory profit.
 
One member could not attend the meeting because she was at the temple.

loans.use: to purchase three superior piglets and feed.

loans.name: Bernabe

texts.en:
Bernabe is a rice farmer. He cultivates rice on his one hectare of farmland to earn an income. 

He and his wife have two children.

Bernabe needs to obtain farm supplies essential to the cultivation of his rice field, but he is suffering from shortage of capital. He is therefore seeking the additional capital of PhP 15,000, which he will use to buy farm inputs such as fertilizers, herbicides, and insecticides. He knows that the application of complete farm inputs to his rice crops will enable him to obtain a better yield and a larger income with which to support his family. 

He is grateful to his Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy essential inputs such as fertilizers, herbicides, and insecticides for his rice farm

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.en:
Leonardo is a rice farmer. For more than 20 years, he has planted and harvested rice crops on his one hectare of farmland. 

Leonardo would like to keep his rice farming business productive and profitable. He is therefore asking for financial support in the form of a loan amounting to PhP 10,000. He will use his loan funds to buy sacks of fertilizers and insecticides for his rice field. 

With continued access to loan assistance, Leonardo hopes that he can someday expand his rice farm.

loans.use: to buy sacks of fertilizers and insecticides for his rice field

loans.name: Cita

texts.en:
Due to the high cost of commodities and school fees, Cita has been engaged in making and selling soft brooms to help her husband in generating income. She is 46 years old and has seven schooling children. Despite financial hardship, she and her husband aim to continue sending their children to school so that they will become professionals in the future. 

To achieve this, Cita wants to continue and strengthen her business to increase her income. Having inadequate capital, she wants to avail a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy tiger grass, rattan and plastics needed in making soft brooms for sale. Through hard work and strong determination, Cita believes that she will make her business more profitable.

loans.use: to buy tiger grass, rattan and plastics needed in making soft brooms for sale.

loans.name: Efren

texts.en:
Efren has joined PMPC and availed the needed capital for his hog-raising business. He is thankful for the capital it extends to a small time borrower like him. 

Efran is able to turn the tide in his favor and has made good sales these days. He wants to take advantage of the good fortune. Recently, he availed a loan to purchase bags of animal feeds and boosters. In the future, he hopes to build a decent home for the family.

loans.use: to purchase bags of animal feeds and boosters.

loans.name: Ayuba

texts.en: Ayuba is a 30-year- old farmer from Gidan Mayau Rumi. As a Babban Gona member, Ayuba, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ayuba can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the National average of 14. However, Ayuba is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Ayuba said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children; , and in 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Joseph joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Afalos,Frisilia, and Ibrahim. Joseph is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Joseph will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Joseph can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Joseph is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Angel Guzmaro

texts.es:
Ángel Guzmaro tiene 31 años de edad, vive con su esposa e hijos, en casa propia en una comunidad pequeña en la zona urbana de Zaña y goza con buenas referencias personales y laborales de parte de sus vecinos, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

El se dedica a la crianza de ganado vacuno y producción de leche, desde hace más de 5, su negocio se encuentra ubicado en la parte posterior de su domicilio, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 3 000 nuevos soles para la compra de una vaca lechera y de esta manera ofrecer la leche y venta de queso fresco que se elabora artesanalmente.
texts.en:
Angel Guzmaro is 31 years old. He lives with his wife and children in his own home, in a small community of the Zaña urban area. He enjoys good personal and work references from his neighbors.

The local population works in agriculture, commerce, and raising livestock. This area is located in the Chiclayo province of the Lambayeque region, on the north coast of Peru.

For over five years, he has made a living raising cattle for milk production. His business is located behind his home.

He has requested a loan of 3,000 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa to buy a dairy cow, so that he can offer for sale the milk, and fresh cheese that is traditionally crafted.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sovannary

texts.en:
Sovannary is a widow with four children. One of her children is a garment worker and two are students. They all live in Takeo Province, Cambodia. 

She is a rice seller and has been in this business since 2005. They can earn approximately $13 per day. Now Sovannary would like to apply for a loan of $1,000 to buy groceries to resell. This loan will help her have a bigger business. In the future, she is going to open a beauty salon for her daughter and support the two children who are students to go to university.

loans.use: To buy groceries to resell.

loans.name: Manuela

texts.en:
Manuela is a 54-year-old married woman with two children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Manuela 's house was destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. She has restarted her general store business and is committed to regaining what she lost. 

Manuela is taking out a PHP 9,871 housing loan through NWTF to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family.

Manuela has been with NWTF since 2012 in her pursuit to rise out of poverty. With your help, She will be able to start once more in a new home. In the future, Manuela would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is a widow who works hard to support her family. She sells frozen foods to earn an income. She has been engaged in this business for six years.

She has requested a PhP 13,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more packs of frozen foods to offer for sale to her customers.

Marilyn's goal is to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase packs of frozen foods to offer for sale to her customers

loans.name: Mercy Ann

texts.en:
Mercy Ann, 34, is married and has six children. Five of her children are in school.

Mercy Ann and her family survived super typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines on November 8, 2013, but her business and family home were wiped out. 

Mercy Ann is taking out a housing loan of 9,714 Philippine pesos to purchase building materials and pay for construction labour to build a house for her family. 

Mercy Ann has been with the Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation since 2011. She plans to recover financially through her general store business.

With your help, Mercy Ann can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon Haiyan. In the future, she would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labour.

loans.name: Ana Yesenia

texts.es:
Ana de 20 años de edad,  vive con sus padres y sus hermanos.  Ella trabaja vendiendo productos por catalogo desde hace 3 años, de esas ventas obtiene sus ingresos para su mantenimiento y ayudar con algunos gastos del hogar, ya que ademas con sus padres trabaja la agricultura  en la siembra de jicamas .  

El préstamo que esta solicitando, es para comprar los fertilizantes para el cultivo de jicama,  ya que se llego la época de cultivar y no les alcanza el dinero; espera que todo le salga bien para obtener buenos resultados al final de la producción.

Ana planea  tener su propia familia y seguir cultivando la tierra con los granos básicos  como (frijol,maíz, sorgo y la jicama ) y cultivar unas 16 tareas de cada uno para así tener lo básico y poder venderle a la gente mas cómodo para generar un bien en común.
texts.en:
Ana, age 20, lives with her parents and siblings. She has sold goods from catalogs for three years, earning income for her own expenses and to help support the household. Ana also helps her parents on their farm, planting jicamas [a root crop similar to a turnip].  

Ana is applying for a loan to purchase fertilizers for the jicama crop as the planting season has arrived and her parents lack the money to purchase supplies. The family hopes the crops will do well this season and yield an abundant harvest. 

Ana plans to start her own family one day, but she will also keep farming the land. She plans to grow crops such as beans, corn, sorghum, and jicama, dedicating 1,100 square meters to each crop. This plan should yield a harvest that Ana can then sell to customers at a decent but price, benefiting Ana and her customers.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for her Mexican yam crop.

loans.name: Mergen

texts.en:
Mergen is a fish vendor who works hard to support her family. She has been engaged in her business for 25 years.

She has requested a loan in the amount of PhP 29,500 through NWTF in order to purchase more fish to offer for sale to her customers.

In the future, Mergen would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fish to offer for sale

loans.name: Iliya

texts.en: Iliya is a 47-year-old farmer from Gidan Mayau Rumi.  As a Babban Gona member, Iliya is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Iliya can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Iliya is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Iliya is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Sani,  and Peter. Iliya’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Thon

texts.en:
Thon, age 61, is a widow with three children. Two of them are garment workers and another is a chef. Together, they can earn approximately $11 per day. The family lives in the province of Kampong Speu.

Thon would like to apply for a loan in the amount of $400 to buy much-needed appliances for her home, as well as some decorations. This loan will greatly improve her house and help her live in better conditions.

loans.use: to buy much-needed appliances for her home, as well as some decorations

loans.name: Isah

texts.en: Isah is a 45-year-old farmer from G/Mayau Rumi. As a Babban Gona member Isah is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members Isah can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However Isah is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked Isah said “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family. In 5 years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.” With this loan Isah is on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Julius Ummaru

texts.en: Julius Ummaru is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Julius Ummaru joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Fatrik,Paul, and Samaila. Julius Ummaru is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Julius Ummaru will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Julius Ummaru can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Julius Ummaru is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Marath

texts.en:
Marath, 22, is single and lives with his mother in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. He works as a tailor and can earn approximately $5 per day. 

He would like to apply for a loan of $1,000 to buy cloth to sell to his customers. This loan will help him when he is short of money to buy cloth.

In the future, he is going to expand his business and offer sewing classes.

loans.use: To buy cloth to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Naneth

texts.en:
Naneth, age 45, saw her business and home destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines on November 8, 2013. She has since restarted her fish vending business and now needs to provide her family with safe shelter. 

She and her husband have five children, two of whom are still in school. She works very hard to provide for them.

Naneth has requested a loan in the amount of PhP 9,360 through NWTF in order to purchase materials with which to rebuild her family home. With her loan funds, she will buy building materials and pay for construction labor.

Naneth is committed to rebuilding her family's devastated life. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy building materials and pay for construction labor in order to rebuild her family home

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios works hard to support her family. On November 8, 2013, her business and home were wiped out by super typhoon Haiyan.

She has restarted her food vending business and is now requesting a housing loan of 8,471 Philippine pesos through the Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation. She will use the loan to purchase building materials and pay for construction labour to build a house for her family.

With your help, Remedios will be able to rebuild her devastated life sooner. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labour.

loans.name: Pablita

texts.en:
Pablita, age 54, is a seamstress. This hard-working entrepreneur has operated her sewing business for seven years.

She and her husband have four children, one of whom is still in school. 

Pablita requested a loan in the amount of PhP 18,000 through NWTF. She will use her loan funds to buy additional materials for her sewing business.

Her goal is to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy materials for her sewing business

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie would like to finish her Master's degree in order to gain a higher standard of education, as well as to obtain access to promotions on her job. Her goal is to attain job improvements through this investment. 

Rosemarie's income goes primarily toward the daily sustenance of her family. For this reason, she has requested a loan from GDMPC, which she will use to pay the tuition fees for her Master's degree. 

Her aim for the future is to provide her family with a better standard of living.

loans.use: to pay tuition fees for her Master's degree

loans.name: Magdalino

texts.en: Magdalino has mastered his "lechon" (roasted pig) business and is commercially doing well in Aloran and nearby towns and cities. He has the mouth watering taste of lechon that is most sought for special occasions. Magdalino wanted to have enough inventory so that he would not miss business opportunities. He applied for a loan to purchase additional heads of pigs for his lechon business. Magdalino hopes to expand his lechon outlets for added income.

loans.use: to purchase additional heads of pigs for roasting

loans.name: Mercidita

texts.en:
Mercidita, 48, is married with five children. Two of her children are currently in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Mercidita has a tailoring business in the Philippines. She has requested a loan of 18,000 Philippine pesos through the Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation. She will use the loan to buy additional materials for her business, including fabric, threads and zippers.

Mercidita has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional materials, like fabric, threads and zippers, for her business.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca, 49, is a widow with five children. She and her family survived super typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines on November 8, 2013, but her business and family home were wiped out. 

Rebecca is taking out a housing loan of 8,314 Philippine pesos to purchase building materials and pay for construction labour to build a house for her family. 

Rebecca has been a borrower with the Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation since 2012. She plans to recover financially through her food vending business.

With your help, Rebecca can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon Haiyan. In future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labour.

loans.name: Juan

texts.es: Juan tiene 44 años de edad, vive en el municipio de Sololá, departamento de Sololá, tiene 4 hijos el primero ya es mayor de edad y trabaja, el segundo tiene 16 años de edad, el tercero tiene 13 años de edad y el cuarto tiene 10 años de edad, todos estudian, Juan se dedica a la compra y venta de ropa típica, él vio una oportunidad de poner su negocio ya que la distancia al departamento es lejos e instaló la venta en su casa desde hace 10 años, lo ayuda su esposa e hijas en la venta, también hace trabajos de albañilería, Juan necesita un crédito por un monto de Q. 8,000.00 para comprar más mercadería, ya al tener más surtido su negocio le genera un poco más de ganancia y tiene más clientela, el sueño de Juan es tener mucho más grande su negocio en el futuro para atender de una mejor manera a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Juan is 44 years old, married, and the father of four children. He lives in the town of Sololá, which is also the name of the surrounding department. The oldest of Juan's four children is grown and works, while the three younger children, ages 16, 13, and 10, are all in school. 

Juan has bought and sold traditional clothing for 10 years. He started this business in his home when he recognized the opportunity that the location afforded him. His home is rather far from town, and therefore a convenient shopping location. Juan's wife and children help him with the business, and he also works in construction. 

Juan needs a loan of 8,000 quetzales to purchase more merchandise. Expanding his inventory will provide a small boost to Juan's income and attract more customers. Juan hopes to expand his business substantially and provide better service to his customers.

loans.use: to purchase traditional clothing

loans.name: Ashiru

texts.en: Ashiru is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Ashiru joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Adamu, Tasiu  and  Buhari. Ashiru is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Ashiru will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Ashiru can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Ashiru said “I plan to use the money I make this year to expand my farmland”. Ashiru is not thinking about just this year; he said, “in 5 years, I want to become the  most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Nurjon

texts.en:
Nurjon runs an appliance and electronics store to earn an income. He has been engaged in his business for more than four years, and he has improved his income significantly since he started this enterprise. He lives in the village of Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur, with his wife and child.

Nurjon has joined GDMPC and has requested a loan in order to purchase new equipment and tools to expand the business. 

He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to improve his family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase new equipment and tools to expand his appliance and electronics sales business

loans.name: M. Stalha Magudadi

texts.en: M. Stalha Magudadi is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. M. Stalha Magudadi joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Murtala, Isah, and  Ashiru. M. Stalha Magudadi is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, M. Stalha Magudadi will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, M. Stalha Magudadi can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” M. Stalha Magudadi is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Suraja

texts.en: Suraja is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Suraja joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for himself and his children. Suraja is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Suraja will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Suraja can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Suraja said “I plan to use the money I make this year to expand my farmland”. Suraja is not thinking about just this year; he said, “in 5 years, I want to become the  most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Sani Musa

texts.en: Sani Namusa is a farmer from Dogon Juri.  As a Babban Gona member, Sani Namusa is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Sani Namusa can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Sani Namusa is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; Yusuf and Abdulkadir. My overall goal is to become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Musa

texts.en: Musa is a 38-year-old farmer from Dogon Juri.  As a Babban Gona member, Musa is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Musa can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Musa is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; Jamilu, Zahara, and Hassan. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es: Doña Francisca, tiene 57 años de edad, esta soltera, tiene dos hijos y vive con ellos en el municipio de San Francisco, Yojoa, Cortes. Hace doce años que ella decidió por establecer una pulpería para vender productos de abarrotería como granos básicos, manteca, azúcar, arroz, frijoles, productos de aseo, cereales, leche, huevos churros, pan etc. Siempre quiere mantener surtida la pulpería y ha solicitado un préstamo por 10,000 lempiras para comprar granos básicos, productos de aseo, lácteos, refrescos, condimentos y otros. Su plan es que su negocio siga generando ingresos para el sostenimiento familiar.
texts.en: Francisca is 57 years old. She is single and has two children that she lives with in the municipality of San Francisco, Yojoa, Cortes. Twelve years ago she decided to establish a small store to sell grocery products like basic grains, lard, sugar, rice, beans, cleaning products, cereals, milk, eggs, churros, bread, etc. She always wants to keep her store stocked and she has requested a loan of 10,000 HNL to buy basic grains, cleaning products, dairy products, soft drinks, spices and others. Her plan is for her store to continue to generate income for the family's sustenance.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, cleaning products, dairy products, soft drinks, spices and others to stock her business.

loans.name: Mukaila

texts.en: Mukaila remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Mukaila, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Mukaila  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Mukaila   With this loan, Mukaila is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is 60 years old and married with seven children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Rosalinda runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell in her general store.

She has been in this business for three years, and sells a variety of items such as snack foods, diapers, sanitary pads, cooking oil, noodles, canned goods, etc. 

Rosalinda would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell in her general store

loans.name: Sofania

texts.en:
Sofania works hard to support her family. She is married, and has a tailoring business in the Philippines.

Sofania requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more materials for her business.

She has been in this business for 15 years now.

In the future, Sofania would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more materials for her business

loans.name: Haruna

texts.en: Haruna remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Haruna, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Haruna  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Haruna   With this loan, Haruna is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Restituta

texts.en: Restituta has finally saved for the repair of her house, but she lacks a little amount to pay for the labor expenses. She recently received a loan from PMPC to pay for the labor costs. Restituta has constantly sought financial help from the Cooperative, and is thankful to be a member in good standing.

loans.use: to pay for labor costs for house repair

loans.name: Nelso

texts.es:
Nelso tiene 29 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Buenos Aires, una comunidad que se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Morropon que pertenece a la Región Piura costa norte del Perú.

El se dedica a cultivar las frutas, actividad que realiza desde hace más de 2 años, su negocio se encuentra ubicado en su domicilio, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 1 000 nuevos soles para la compra de plátano y de esta manera abastecer su negocio para ofrecer sus clientes.
texts.en:
Nelso is 29 years old and lives in the district of Buenos Aires, located in the Province of Morropon that belongs to the Piura Region on the North Coast of Peru. The people of this community work in agriculture, commerce and raise livestock.

Nelso works growing fruit, an occupation he has done for more than two years. His business is located at his place of residence. He has requested a loan from Edpyme Alternativa for 1000 PEN to buy bananas and in this way stock his business to offer to his clients.

loans.use: to buy bananas to stock his business.

loans.name: Fernando

texts.en:
Fernando learned about Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative and the financial assistance it gives. He tried his luck on doing a business focusing on farming activities. He feels he owes his fortune to the Cooperative for having trusted him with the money he used as capital. 

He took another loan amount to pay for seedlings and compost. This will give his farming income a big boost. 

Fernando looks for better business opportunities and would love to be a the position to help others.

loans.use: to pay for seedlings and compost

loans.name: Necasia

texts.en:
Necasia is juggling a business and supervising the renovation of their home. She hopes to live comfortably, with a house of good roofing supported by her loan of Php 20,000. 

She hopes to maintain her membership in good standing with a good repayment record. Matter that Necasia has given a priority as a microfinance member of PMPC. This is what she is thankful for when all her financing needs on her retailing business where supported by PMPC.

loans.use: to pay for a house renovation

loans.name: Shuhrat

texts.ru: Шухрат является повторным клиентом ИМОН. Он очень честный и ответственный человек. Шухрат разведённый и имеет одного сына. Он сам воспитывает сына. Шухрат единственный кормилец в семье и поэтому он трудится с раннего утра до позднего вечера, чтобы зарабатывать на жизнь. Шухрат работает в стройках. Он строитель. Еще он имеет 2 га земли, где выращивает зерно. Шухрат нуждается в автомашине для развития своего бизнеса, то есть для транспортировки зерна, а также для строительных работ. Он запрашивает займ на сумму 7000 сомони для покупки автомашины. Он ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en:
Shuhrat is a repeat customer of IMON International. He is very honest and responsible person. Shuhrat is divorced and has one son. He raises his son on his own.

Since Shuhrat is the only breadwinner in the family, he works from early morning until late at night in order to earn a living. Shuhrat works on construction sites as a builder. He also has two hectares of land where he grows corn. 

To grow his business, Shukrat needs a car in order to transport seeds as well as for his construction work. He is requesting a loan of 7,000 Somoni to buy a car. He awaits your kindness.

loans.use: to buy car for using in business

loans.name: Zosima

texts.en:
Zosima works hard to support her family. She is married, and has a bicycle transport business in the Philippines. In the picture, Zosima is with her husband who manages to drive the bicycle.

Zosima requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy an additional bicycle for her business.

She has been in this business for nine years now.

Zosima would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy an additional bicycle for her business

loans.name: Penelope

texts.en:
Penelope is 23 years old. She is a proud single mother with a 10-month-old baby, Crisen. For the past three years, Penelope has been working for a Zoona entrepreuer as a mobile money shop teller. Through hard work and demonstrating the ability to succeed, Penelope has been given the opportunity to start her own Zoona mobile money franchise. She is excited about the chance this will bring her to increase her income and improve the opportunities for herself and her young child. 

Penelope will set up her Zoona mobile money outlet in the thriving Copperbelt region of Zambia in the town of Chingola. She has located a great spot in a busy market where many people pass by throughout the day. When Penelope receives her loan, she will use the funds to purchase a trading booth to operate her business out of and a quality mobile phone which she can use to service her customers. 

Penelope sees a great opportunity to improve her standard of living by receiving this selection to operate her very own business. She already has plans for expanding her business to operate in multiple locations throughout the region. With her improved income, Penelope plans to provide a quality upbringing for her young child.

loans.use: To purchase a trading booth to operate her business out of and a quality mobile phone which she can use to service her customers

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Hello lenders! Meet Joseph, 29 years of age, he is very hardworking, polite and a go-getter. He hails from the Kitale area of Kenya, an area that is blessed with favorable weather patterns and is always referred to as the “food basket “area of Kenya. 

Joseph is very hard working and has been doing farming for the past five years; through the fruits of his hard work he has been able to take care of his family needs. Through practicing mixed farming, that is dairy farming and crop farming, Joseph has been able to always get good returns from these two ventures and he has always managed to put food on the table for his family.

Joseph is very enterprising and he wants to start poultry farming so that he can supplement his income and assure his family of a bright future. That is why he is seeking a loan of KES 40,000 to buy poultry. 

Through the income that he will generate from poultry farming, he will be able to comfortably assure his child of uninterrupted learning, because he will be able to pay tuition fees and provide all other basic needs that his family may require.

Joseph is a strong believer that education is the key to success, and that’s why he will do anything positively good to assure his child of a good future. Joseph projects that through increased profits from egg selling and poultry selling, he will have a great impact on the society and his family.

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Musa Bakano

texts.en: Musa Bakano is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Musa Bakano joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Zaharaddeen, Mubarak, and  Yusuf. Musa Bakano is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Musa Bakano will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Musa Bakano can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, his said, “I plan to use the money  to build a better home.” Musa Bakano is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Yakubu Manja

texts.en: Yakubu Manja remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Yakubu Manja, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yakubu Manja  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community” expressed Yakubu Manja   With this loan, Yakubu Manja is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Xiomara Esmeralda

texts.es:
Xiomara de 33 años de edad, vive con su familia,  su esposo trabaja es militar y ella se dedica a a la agricultura, son padres de dos hijos de 8 y 3 años de edad respectivamente.  

 Xiomara no asistió a la escuela, ya que sus padres no le dieron la oportunidad de estudiar y ella aprendió a leer con programas de alfabetización.

Ella desde muy pequeña aprendió el oficio de cultivar los granos básicos, ya que para sus padres era lo mas importante.

El préstamo que esta solicitando a CREDICAMPO, es para comprar fertilizantes, ya que el cultivo necesita para tener un buen desarrollo y para dar una buena cosecha.

En el futuro planea tener unos mejores ingresos de la agricultura, ya que sueña con cultivar unas 30 tareas de cultivos de maíz y  frijol para poder ayudar a sus hijos a salir adelante con sus estudios y sean unas buenas personas en la sociedad.
texts.en:
Xiomara is 33 years old and lives with her family. Her husband works in the military and she works in agriculture. They have two children who are 3 and 8 years old.

Xiomara didn't get a formal education because her parents did not send her to school but she learned to read through literacy programs. From a young age she learned how to grow staple crops, because her parents felt this was the most important skill to learn.

Xiomara is asking for a loan from CREDICAMPO [Kiva Field Partner] to buy fertilizer, which her crops need in order to grow well and produce a good harvest. In the future she would like to get more income from her crops, and her dream is to be able to grow 30 plots of corn and beans in order to help her children continue with their schooling and become good people in society.

loans.use: buy fertilizer, which her crops need in order to grow well and produce a good harvest.

loans.name: Samaila Mohammad

texts.en: Samaila Mohammad is a 36-year-old farmer from Kaza.  As a Babban Gona member, Samaila Mohammad is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Samaila Mohammad can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Samaila Mohammad is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; Andorra, Usman, and  Tijjani. My overall goal is to make more money for myself and my family”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Ibrahim joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Sha'Aibu, Basiru, and  Usman. Ibrahim is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Ibrahim will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Ibrahim can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, his said, “I plan to use the money  to build a better home.” Ibrahim is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Catalina Lucy

texts.es:
Catalina Lucy tiene 35 años de edad, de estado civil casado tiene 2 hijos, vive con su familia en este mismo distrito de Oyotún, una zona rural que se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

Ella se dedica a la crianza y comercialización de animales como patos, gallos, gallinas, pollos, desde hace varios años, su negocio se encuentra ubicado en la parte posterior de su domicilio, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 2 000 nuevos soles para la compra de mayor cantidad de animales para ofrecer a sus clientes y de esta manera generar mayores ingresos para su familia.
texts.en:
Catalina Lucy is 35, married, and has two children. She lives with her family in the Oyotún district, a rural area devoted to agriculture, business, and livestock in the province of Chiclayo, Lambayeque region, on the north coast of Peru.
She has raised and sold animals like ducks, roosters, and hens, for several years. Her business is located in the back of her home. She has requested a loan of 2,000 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa for the purchase of a greater quantity of animals to sell, in order to generate a greater in come for her family.

loans.use: to buy a larger quantity of animals to stock her business.

loans.name: La Vecindad De Quesquento Group

texts.es:
La socia Anacleta pertenece al banco comunal LA VECINDAD DE QUESQUENTO,el banco está ubicado en el distrito de Quellouno en la provincia de La Convención y departamento de Cusco.
La socia tiene 54 años de edad tiene 02hijos y es conviviente, la socia alterna sus  actividades diarias con el negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia lleva buen tiempo con su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia  vende diferentes tipos de productos como arroz, azúcar, leche entre otros, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de arroz, leche entre otros.
La socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgad y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
Los demás socios se dedican al negocio de tienda de abarrotes, crianza de animales, agricultura.
texts.en:
Anacleta belongs to the La Vecindad de Quesquento communal bank, located in the Quellouno district in the province of La Convención, Cusco department.
She is 54, has two children, and lives with her partner. She alternates her daily chores with her grocery business. She has been in the business for a while and it is going well thanks to the hard work she puts into her business every day. She sells different kinds of products such as rice, sugar, and milk. She wants to be able to keep working in order to continue supporting her family.
She is requesting this loan for the purchase of rice, milk, and other items.
She is grateful for this loan and promises to repay her quotas.
The other members have grocery businesses, raise animals, or work in agriculture.

loans.use: to purchase rice, milk, and other items.

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en:
Sokhom, 50, lives in Preah Sdach district, Prey Veng province. He owns a farmland on which he grows rice and sells to the local dealers. Until now, it has almost been thirty years since he has been a farmer. By working very hard, he is able to make approximately USD 5 per day.

Sokhom would like to improve his living standards by having clean energy for household use. Because of the lack of capital, he is asking for a loan to build a biogas digester under the project of NBP (National Biogas Program) in partnering with HKL. After an initial investment in this system, he hopes that he won’t spend much money on fuel and have less smoke from wood or charcoal. Thanks to the green loan program with a special rate offered by HKL, Sokhom’s family can gain access to a clean energy while protecting the environment.

loans.use: to build a biogas digester

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is 27 years old and operates four Zoona mobile money outlets in the city of Ndola, Zambia. This is Mercy’s third Kiva loan. She successfully repaid her first loan and continues to make timely repayments on her second loan, all while scaling her business rapidly.

Mercy’s first Kiva loan empowered her to start running her own business. The second loan that Mercy got helped her increase her float (the amount of mobile money she has available in her business at any given time to serve customers). This enabled Mercy to serve additional customers and consequently earn more profits from commissions. Currently, she employs four young adults.

Mercy is now requesting an additional Kiva loan to scale her business even further. She plans to open three more Zoona mobile money transfer outlets in high traffic areas that have a need for safe, affordable, mobile financial services. She will use the funds to purchase three quality mobile phones and add to her working capital to service customers at the new locations. Mercy will employ three new shop tellers once she begins transacting at her new locations as well.

Mercy would like to take this opportunity to thank Kiva lenders for empowering her to start and grow her business by having financial access to micro-loans.

loans.use: To scale her business by opening up three more Zoona mobile money transfer outlets

loans.name: Venancio

texts.es: Don Venancio, tiene 57 años de edad, casado, vive junto a su esposa y dos hijos en el municipio de San Pedro Sula. El tiene su propio negocio desde hace 12 años donde sostiene a su familia, vende verduras como ser papas, chile, tomate, cebolla, repollo, habichuela, pataste, bananos, aguacates, zanahoria, etc. en forma ambulante movilizándose en una carreta de madera, esta actividad la realiza de lunes a jueves y los fines de semana vende en los puntos de vendedores o ferias del agricultor. El préstamo que solicita es el cuarto ciclo y es por 15,000 lempiras para comprar verduras frescas como tomate, chile, pataste, habichuela, papas, zanahoria, banano, yuca, etc. y vender, con el propósito de mantener el negocio y sacar adelante a su familia.
texts.en:
Venancio is 57 years old. He lives with his wife and two children in the municipality of San Pedro Sula. He has had his own business for 12 years to support his family. He sells vegetables like potatoes, chilies, tomato, onions, cabbage, kidney beans, chayote, bananas, avocados, carrots, etc. in the streets from his wooden cart. He does this from Monday to Thursday and on weekends he sells at the venders stalls or the agricultural markets.

The loan he is requesting is his fourth cycle and is for 15,000 HNL to buy fresh vegetables like tomato, chiles, potatoes, chayote, kidney beans, carrots, bananas, yucca, etc. to resell. His plan is to maintain his business and get ahead with his family.

loans.use: to buy fresh vegetables like tomato, chiles, potatoes, chayote, kidney beans, carrots, bananas, yucca, etc.

loans.name: Sebastian Alarico

texts.es:
Sebastián Alarico tiene 57 años de edad, de estado civil casado, vive con su familia en el distrito de Oyotún, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

El se dedica a brindar servicios agrícolas, contando con herramientas propias, contando con experiencia desde hace varios años, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 1 500 nuevos soles para la compra de insumos agrícolas para mejoramiento de infraestructura, dicha inversión le servirá para tener en mejores condiciones sus equipos y herramientas.
texts.en:
Sebastián Alarico is 57, married, and lives with his family in the Oyotún district. The population works in agriculture, commerce, and livestock. Oyotun is located in the province of Chiclayo, belonging to the Lambayeque region, on the north coast of Peru.
Sebastian Alarico provides agricultural services with his own tools. He has many years' experience. He has requested a loan of 1500 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa for the purchase of agricultural supplies for improving infrastructure. This investment will allow him to keep his tools and equipment in better condition.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies in order to continue offering a service.

loans.name: Roidah

texts.en:
Roidah is 53 years old. She is married with four children ages 28, 25, 21, and 20. 

She operates her own business at one of Lusaka’s busiest markets. Her business deals in the sale of Coca-Cola products on wholesale to other small businesses in her community. She  employs two people who help her in the day-to-day operations of the business. She has been running her business for many years and understands the importance of having enough empty crates to order additional drinks from the suppliers.

Roidah says her business is good, but the one thing holding her back is that she needs to increase her turnover in selling by having more stock on hand. She explains how the number of drinks she can order is directly dependent on the amount of empty stock she has. If she can acquire more capital to purchase additional stock, this will help scale up her business and earn Roidah more profit. 

She is hopeful that once she has more crates, her profit margins will increase by having additional turnover in the business. She hopes to use the profits from her business to purchase a piece of land and build a home for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional empty crates so that she can order more stock

loans.name: María Felisa

texts.es: María Felisa tiene 30 años de edad, es soltera, vive en el municipio de Sololá, departamento de Sololá, se dedica a comprar y a vender ropa típica, la venta lo tiene instalado en su casa y en los días de mercado de la aldea sale a vender, porque mucha gente no tiene la facilidad de ir hasta en el municipio para hacer sus compras, clientela que aprovecha ella para negociar,  anteriormente su mamá era la encargada del negocio,  ella y su mama iniciaron con el negocio desde hace 10 años, María Felisa necesita un crédito de un monto de Q. 7,000.00 para comprar más mercadería, ella comenta que entre más surtida esta su negocio obtiene más ganancia y tiene más clientela, ella sueña con tener su negocio mucho más surtido y más grande.
texts.en:
